newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Indonesian rubber falls on poor demand.
newsitem.headline: Indonesian rubber falls on poor demand.

text.p: Indonesian rubber prices fell further in early trading on Thursday on prolonged sluggish demand, traders said.

They said the benchmark SIR20 was sold overnight to U.S. buyers at 45.75 U.S. cents/lb for June shipment fob Palembang, compared with Wednesday's offer price of 46.50. Offer prices also fell in other cities, they said.

"Prices are falling again and again because of a lack of inquiries from buyers," said one trader. Traders said offer prices fell to 46.25 fob Medan, to 46.00 fob Padang and Surabaya and to 45.75 fob Pontianak and Jambi.
"We earlier believed that prices will rebound after bottoming out at 45.00...but seen from this kind of situation, I believe it will slide further to 40.00," said another trader.
"Those traders in Medan who were waiting for better prices have given up and they are willing to sell at 46.25," he added.
Traders said some buyers sought to make use of the cheap prices to buy rubber for August and September shipment, but traders refused to sell.
